description: xxd - make a hex dump or do the reverse.

global_flags.description: style,  when  using
This does not change the hexadecimal representation. The option is meaningless in combinations with -r, -p or -i.

the same color depending on the hex-value. Mostly helping to differ‐ entiate  printable and non-printable characters.  when is never, always, or auto.  When the  $NO_COLOR  environment  variable  is set, colorization will be disabled.
Default off.

This option writes octets as eight digits "1"s and "0"s instead of  a normal  hexadecimal dump. Each line is preceded by a line number in hexadecimal and followed by an ASCII (or EBCDIC)  representa‐ tion.  The  command  line  switches -p, -i do not work with this mode.
-b: 6).  Max  256.   No  maximum for -ps. With -ps, 0 results in one long line of output.
show offset in decimal instead of hex.

Switch  to  little-endian  hex  dump.   This  option treats byte groups as words in little-endian byte order.  The default group‐ ing of 4 bytes may be changed using -g.  This  option  only  ap‐ plies to the hex dump, leaving the ASCII (or EBCDIC) representa‐ tion  unchanged.   The  command  line switches -r, -p, -i do not work with this mode.

hex  characters or eight bit digits each) by a whitespace.  Specify -g 0 to sup‐ press grouping.  <Bytes> defaults to 2 in normal mode, 4 in lit‐ tle-endian  mode and 1 in bits mode.  Grouping does not apply to PostScript or include style.
No hex  dumping is performed.
output in C include file style.
stop after <len> octets.
|  -name name Override  the variable name output when -i is used. The array is named name and the length is named name_len.
add <off> to the displayed file position.
Also  known  as plain hex dump style.
output in postscript plain hexdump style.

operation: convert (or patch) hex dump into binary.  If not writing to stdout, xxd writes into its output  file  without truncating it. Use the combination -r -p to read plain hexadeci‐ mal dumps without line number information and without a particu‐ lar column layout. Additional whitespace and line breaks are al‐ lowed  anywhere.  Use  the combination -r -b to read a bits dump instead of a hex dump.

+ indicates that  the  seek  is  relative to the current stdin file position (meaningless when not reading from stdin).  - indicates that the seek should be that many characters from the end  of  the  input (or if combined with +: before the current stdin file position). Without -s option, xxd starts at the current file position.
Use upper-case hex letters. Default is lower-case.
